review.title: Computational Narrative Intelligence: A Human-Centered Goal for Artificial Intelligence
review.abstract: Narrative intelligence is the ability to craft, tell, understand, and respond affectively to stories. We argue that instilling artificial intelligences with computational narrative intelligence affords a number of applications beneficial to humans. We lay out some of the machine learning challenges necessary to solve to achieve computational narrative intelligence. Finally, we argue that computational narrative is a practical step towards machine enculturation, the teaching of sociocultural values to machines.

sections.heading: Author Keywords
sections.text: Artificial intelligence, machine learning, narrative intelligence, machine enculturation

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: We tell stories dozens of times a day: at the dinner table to share experiences; through fables to teach values; through journalism to communicate important events; and in entertainment films, novels, and computer games to have fun. Stories also motivate people to learn why they form the backbone of training scenarios and case studies at school or in the workplace. Despite the importance of storytelling as part of the human experience, computers still cannot create and tell reliable new stories, nor understand stories that are told by people. When computers tell stories, via an e-book or computer game, they will simply restore something that was written by a human being. They do not participate in the culture in which we are immersed, as manifested by journalistic news articles, the movies we watch, or the books we read.

sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to play by the rules they have imposed on themselves.

sections.heading: MACHINE ENCULTURATION
sections.text: In addition to the applications described ealier - and assuming that the above challenges can be met - computerized intelligence can be a path toward enculturation. [29] Machine enculturation is the act of injecting social norms, customs, values, and labels into computers so that they can (a) more easily relate to us, and (b) avoid creating (physical or psychological) or social dislocations. In a perfect world, humanity would come up with a user manual that we can easily insert into a computer. However, for any sufficiently complex domain, such as the real world, coding a comprehensive set of values or rewards is necessary to recreate sociocultural behavior, it is unsustainable.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this position paper, we argue that future artificial intelligence should be equipped with computer-assisted narrative intelligence so that it can act like humans or understand human desires, needs, and desires. Artificial intelligence, equipped with computer-assisted narrative intelligence, can be more effective in communicating with people and explaining their behavior. Finally, computer-assisted narrative intelligence could be a practical step toward machine enculturation.
